Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned about trees.

I feel like I have a new understanding and appreciation for trees now that I have taken this class. I really enjoyed the bonding with other students trudging up the hill at 9am, studying late into the night for exams and going hunting for the tallest tree on campus. I thought it was a fun way to connect with such an important part of nature, even if we went waayyyyy more in depth than I was expecting/necessarily needed.

This class was sort of a smorgasbord of information about trees, a bit of biology, ecology, history, art, music, kind of everything. There wasn't really a broader overarching structure or purpose to the class in my view, more of a collection of interesting information and perspectives.
This course allowed me to engage with many topics related to trees, as well as the physiology of trees and their role in American History. Incredibly interesting.
I am not a science person at all, and I really enjoyed this class! It was interesting to learn random things about trees.
I learned a lot more about trees than I could have ever imagined--how they work on a cellular to a macro level, how they impact our environment, and how humans have impacted how trees grow.
Trees! I learned a whole lot about trees and actually look at the world a different way now. This class is great!
Learned a lot about Trees and Tree related stuff.
Learned a lot about trees and plants and how theyre more relevant to my daily life than I thought

intellectual curiosity. the topics we covered seemed trivial at times from a cursory overview of the syllabus, but once the professor delved into the concepts and details, I was surprised to realize how much I had overlooked by not seeing things with more intellectual curiosity. This is an invaluable thing to have learned.

This course focused mainly on the physiological aspects of trees--we learned a lot about how specific processes in trees work, rather than "global significance" (although in section we covered global significance a little more).
I learned a lot about trees, their benefits to society and the impact of climate change and human actions
This class teaches you the biology behind trees, the science of studying trees, the many different uses for trees, and even a little bit of tree philosophy.
I learned some random biology and ecology with trees facts in between.
I learned way more about the biology and usage of trees than I ever thought I could learn about trees.
tree knowledge

Learned a lot about trees, plants and introductory botany. Also learned about the uses of wood (furniture and musical instruments mostly). In addition, we learned about the changes in conservation and American historical links with trees and forestry.

I gained an overall understanding of tree anatomy and biological function. For not having taken a biology class since high school, I learned a lot of the basic material about tree and plant biology and evolution.
Best class ever.

I have taken many ecology/ biology classes already and have more experience with environmental field work than the average Yale student, and this class was still AMAZING! I loved it, and learned much more than I expected (I was worried it would be redundant for me, but this was not the case). This course provided me with such a strong understanding of tree biology and forest ecology, as well as a much better understanding of forestry (the industry, not just the environmental practices) and how it is connected to every day life, the global market, communities, cities, etc. For this reason, it was such a valuable course for me as an Environmental Studies major because even though it was a very science heavy course, it provided social commentary and improved my way of thinking about conservation in a more practical sense.
I am now a self-proclaimed tree expert and can tell you all about the relationship between auxin and ethylene gas.
Found the subject to be surprisingly interesting. I come away with a general understanding of how trees function and how forests have evolved over time.
I developed a serious knowledge of trees and the environment which I definitely did not have before.
I LEARNED SO MUCH ABOUT TREES OH MY GOODNESS!! Tree botany, tree hormones, tree industries, uses of wood, history of trees and wood uses...

A solid survey of tree anatomy (xylem, phloem, bark, leaf), tree hormones, tree diseases, stand succession, and the practical applications of wood (instruments, furniture, even baseball bats). Basically everything you'd want to know about trees.
I learned about trees, and how they interact with the world.
I learned some facts about trees.

I learned about the biology of trees and also some of the applications including musical instruments, furniture, and environmental management. The course title and description is pretty telling, not really any curveballs in this class.
Comprehensive understanding of tree biology and the role of wood in culture.
I gained a great understanding of tree physiology!!!
How trees work, the environment, the conductance of water and fluids, pests, and a changing environment.
A basic understanding of trees and environmental science.
Plant and tree anatomy, and its applications to broader society, which was interesting.
Learned lots about trees! And now they are integrated into society and how important they are

The physiology of plants, how plants perform various processes to live, how they interact with their environments, and the role that they play in agriculture, building, instrument making, and more! We also discussed more current issues regarding plants such as GMOs and climate change.

This course gave me a better understanding of plant biology and the important processes crucial to a plant's existence and daily functioning. Additionally, I grasped a better understanding of the impact trees have on the planet and how these organisms can detect the continually changing environment and how that impacts humankind.
The class provided a fascinating introduction to botany, with an emphasis on the biological mechanisms and environmental ramifications of trees.
I was able to gain more knowledge about how immensely trees effect the environment and daily processes of humans and all other types of organisms.
I grasped a much better understanding of the natural world around us and our relationship with it. Trees are super cool and Im really glad I got to learn how great they are through this class.
Basic plant/tree biology, economic and social aspects of forestry

We learned about basic plant biology and evolutionary adaptations, and their relation to things like climate change and instrument making. The course moves from the fundamentals of things like photosynthesis and roots to the development of forests to the qualities of wood that influence the sound instruments make. Throughout the lectures are spread interesting facts about unique tree species or traits that keeps the material engaging.

Knowledge of how trees grow, how water moves through them, how they produce their own food!, how they help each other sometimes. I learned how to measure the height and breast-height diameter of a tree using simple field tools. Tree anatomy. Wood variation. Tree diseases. Honestly lots of stuff.

I learned about the interworking of the tree, how a tree interacts with it's environment despite being a sessile organism, and how humans might begin to respond to the levels of carbon in the atmosphere.
I learned a lot about trees and plant biology, as well as the various processes of the greater natural environment.
Lots of knowledge of the environment.
Trees cannot be improved in nature and therefore they cannot be improved in the classroom.

I think not having it at 9am would be huge. The homework got a little confusing at the end because they suddenly piled on top of each other and I never really know when they were due. Same sort of thing with the quizzes.

Strengths: accessibility for non-science majors, field trips, creativity of assignments
Weaknesses: STRUCTURE - the biweekly pacing of quizzes kind of fell apart and felt sort of made up on the fly, the assignments were paced bizarrely and I turned in four of the five assignments in the same week. I also felt like the material of the last five weeks felt trivial compared to the first eight, and thought that the focus on music and furniture was interesting but somewhat inconsequential

This is an amazing class that provides an opportunity to engage in the subject matter that appeals both to non-science and science majors. Fascinating, brilliantly taught, with opportunities to be exposed to material through a variety of avenues.

 The only weakeness of the class is that it is taught at 9am - I almost never missed class but a lot of people did (probably because of how early it's held) and that's a real shame.

Overall the course was very well structured, with clear information. Tests are very straight forward and if you study for them you will be more than alright. Content is interesting for non-science majors.

I do enjoy the field trips and the structure/predictability of the course. The readings were a bit overwhelming though--the textbook is definitely a bit too dense and readings, like American Canopy, should be broken up a bit further, and homework assignments should be spread out beyond the month of April.
More structure would likely help
The discussion section is pointless
Very engaging, section is unorganized with work and a lot of field trips.

The textbook was a weakness. I paid over 100 dollars for a book that was NEVER used. The professor himself said we were not expected to read it. it was a reference in case  we got stuck. I would have liked to known that before making the purchase.
Lectures were not always great but could be really interesting at times. I would have really liked to do more identification which we did barely at all.
Great class, take it!
This course shouldn't be both so early and so far away from most student housing.
It required field work which I felt was truly helpful
The diversity of topics covered as well as the engaging and enthusiastic professor were two of the biggest strengths of this course, and they made it a joy to come to class each Tuesday and Thursday.
Lectures are incredibly boring, only like 25 percent of the class actually shows up.

The TAs run the course. There is such a disparity between the TAs that your course is greatly shaped by your TA. They decide when your PSETs are due and they can spring them upon you at the last second. It is really unorganized.
should be called plant bio

This course is relatively accessible. In addition, we get to go on multiple field trips to get a better idea (from professionals) n the importance of woodwork! Could be improved by having lectures later in the day in a location closer to campus.
no weaknesses

The course is very well balanced with being accessible to all students (including non environmental / non STEM students) while also still being intellectually engaging for students of all skill levels in the subject of ecology/ forestry.

The only weakness of the course was the discussion sections. It is clear that the content of the discussion sections was included to make non-STEM majors more comfortable with engaging in discussions on ecology and plant biology (which is support!), but sometimes the was a lack of connecting the discussion  sections back to the content of the course / lectures that left them feeling irrelevant. Also, because the material in discussion sections was often more artistic than conventional scientific reading, I worry some students were left with misconceptions about the environmental science at hand (for example, after speaking with one of my peers who is a humanities major, I found out he was lead to have a very factually incorrect understanding of natural selection due to the book "What a Plant Knows," which personifies plants for the sake of trying to explain their sensory capabilities. This was very worrying to me.)   

The most serious improvement I recommend is the complete removal of "American Canopy" from the course material. The negative aspects of this book FAR outweighed the few helpful facts and statistics that it provided for discussions. Its erasure of Native Americans was very disturbing to me and detrimental to the understanding that other students have on environmental issues. I worry that many students, especially those not in my discussion section where we addressed the problem, do not even realize how harmful, and racist, it is to exclude indigenous people and people of color from environmental discussions. The book supported the traditionally white-centric approach environmentalism has historically had, and still has today, and I do not think that should be promoted in a Yale, or any college, course. Other material could be found to replace this book that provides the history of forestry in the united states without ignoring and degrading Native Americans.

The lecture's material was really cool and engaging, and the course itself was well-designed. However, it had many weaknesses that limited engagement with the course. It was at the least ideal time (9am), lasted way too long (over an hour twice a week + mandatory section), and was in the least desirable location (all the way up science hill). While the course itself was fine, getting there was a hassle. I definitely think everyone's attendance would've been much higher if it were in a more central location at a later (and maybe shorter) time.

S: good readings for section, interesting homework, reasonable exams

W: lecture slides have too much information, material is weirdly mysterious and not as straightforward as it can be

As an environmental studies class, I was really hoping to learn more about ecology and identification.  I was disappointed to find out it was heavily biology based but still interested nonetheless.  I think a lesser emphasis on tree physiology and more of a focus on forest ecology as a whole would be a better fit. 
 I also do not see the need for a section for this class.  Reading two pieces of literature for a discussion section should not be required in a science credit, for the books provided no insight into the actual course material.  Sections also varied far too much for my liking.  Each TA set their own deadlines, so discussing the classwork with another student was often confusing.  TAs also graded quite differently, which could work for or against you depending on who you had.

I think the course is a lot more interesting than you expect but a little harder than you expect too. I really loved learning the material but some aspects of the course felt unnecessary and did not contribute to overall learning. I felt like reading some of the books for section didn't hugely apply but mainly the music/ furniture homework was a cool idea but I didn't really feel like I learned much from them.

Strengths: Amazing professor - Prof Brodersen  is a fantastic teacher who goes above and beyond to engage students with this class!! Class content is also so interesting and taught very well. TF team is AWESOME. 
Weaknesses: Some of the section readings were a little bit too much - i.e. I didn't have the time to read all of American Canopy, although I would have liked to!!
The course material itself is largely fantastic (tedious memorization of hormones aside). My only advice is that future classes don't take place at 9am far up on Science Hill. That would be great.

Professor Brodersen is great. He is the strength to this course, I do not think it would work without him. 
There were several weaknesses of this course, as I saw it, was that the TFs were not knowledgeable about the subject (evidenced by saying different answers to the same question during office hours, etc), and the class featured much more about tree biology than "global significance."

Craig really tries to make this course engaging by teaching us about trees from a variety of levels and pulling in all kinds of resources. However, its hard to overcome a subject matter that is inherently boring. Sorry Craig.

This course had a lot of assignments and I think there were only a couple of them that could be cut out. The variety of exams and assignments helped to cover the breadth of material the class covered. However, the quizzes were probably unnecessary and were somewhat of an annoyance to have to do within the allotted time. I also hated how this exam was the last day of the exam period, but I guess some class has to take this spot (nothing the professor can do about it). Professor Brodersen's investment and enthusiasm in this class were definitely a plus, he definitely made it easier to wake up and walk to science hill for this 9 am two days a week.

9 a.m. lecture up science hill was a barrier to entry. The discussion sections were pointless, though the visits to the YUAG and musical instrument study were mildly interesting. Homework assignments were useless, whereas the quizzes were really helpful in regimenting study habits. Lecture was not engaging and often muddled.
This course is really awesome and should be a pre-requisite for everyone!
All is good! Sometimes the lecturer could speak more loudly and look at the audience; sometimes was hard to hear him.
Although the class is interesting the lecture and discussions section do not really match well.

I came away with a good general understanding of trees, which was what I was looking for in this class, but so often during the course I felt like we went on long tangents that really did not interest me. A lot of the discussions on saw mills, instruments, and furniture were far less interesting and important to me than the lectures on actual tree biology and ecology, and I think it would be more meaningful to focus the course more in that direction.
Trees were more interesting than I thought they would be. Class was heavily slide-based, so people skipped class as a result. I found lecture interesting, though.
Lectures were interesting for the most part--i though the content was engaging but could have been discussed more in depth.

Strengths: the course is well organized, lectures are interesting, and the PowerPoints are easy to follow. By the end of the course, you will have a very comprehensive understanding of plants and certainly a whole new appreciation for them! Also, there were tons of fun trips that we went on for section... YUAG, Furniture museum, Musical instrument museum. The section assignments were fun too (like trying to find the oldest and tallest trees on campus)! 

Weaknesses: Occasionally, certain topics will feel notes-heavy and a little less interesting than others (for example, learning about different specific plant hormones felt pretty mechanical and less engaging than learning about making instruments from trees).
This course does a great job of relating the properties and biological processes of plants and connecting that with everyday practices, such as farming, woodwind instruments, furniture, and more.
Really well structured course.

The strengths include the well designed lectures and the field projects that enabled us to learn outside of the classroom. The weakness was that there wasnt much discussion of what happened in lecture during sections unless it was a review session for the exam, so having more of that.

The topic is inherently really interesting however the books we read had very little to do with what we were learning in class. The class seemed a little disorganized at times too as we didnt get our first homework assignments until halfway through the semester or so. The professor is really great though and knows a lot about the subject.
More structured lectures, thematic trends

Professor Brodersen is a good lecturer. At times he speaks slightly quickly, but he cares a lot about student engagement with the material. He emphasizes the importance of the science we talk about with contemporary research and technological innovations and loves to share things that he finds interesting. The lectures used a good combination of clarifying lecture slides and in-person explanation by Professor Brodersen. The final was also very well designed: the questions were clear and relied not on pure memorization but a synthesis of understanding from lectures. The relatively early 9am time and long walk to SPL was a bit tiring at times, but he mentioned trying to find a closer location and later start time for future dates.

Strengths: cool topic, sometimes really interesting tidbits and a lot of overall understandings that I now value, clear what will be on the tests, fair amount of content, outside-of-class stuff in section such as tree measuring and instruments was mostly good

Weaknesses: lectures were generally boring. That's the truth of it, even though I was interested in the trees.

The homework assignments (and discussion section readings) didn't always line up with what we were learning in class at the time. It would be helpful if they did line up, so the added assignments didn't feel like a tangent and could aid lectures. Nevertheless, the way that discussion sections were run was well done, and the lectures were given in a way that made them interesting.
The material was very accessible and not difficult for a humanities major to understand.
This course was very 'user-friendly'. I enjoyed it greatly. The improvement that could be made would be in the reading selection, specifically 'The American Canopy'.
This is what a science-for-non-science-majors should be. If you need a science credit, take this class.
Yes. Moderately interesting lectures with minimal workload to fulfill a distribution requirement.
Yes because it's a good feels kind of lecture and it's a good time.

As a gut science, sure, but I think that as an intro EVST course this class needs some reworking to better facilitate student learning and to better strike a middle ground between accessibility and rigor.

As a (natural sciences specific) STEM major, I was mildly skeptical as the course seems to be pitched as for "non-science" majors, somewhat nonspecifically but in a noticeable way. However! This was not the case. The material is presented in a generally accessible way, but it is still very fascinating even if you are a person who studied trees/already knows things about tree systems and forests. Dr. Brodersen is an amazing and engaging professor who really knows how to make material interesting and teach it in a way that you care about it. Readings and field trips provide opportunities to engage with material in unique ways, and the lectures feature some especially interesting topics that bring what's being studied into something that feels incredibly relevant and intriguing. Exams are fair and overall the topics are fairly scientific but not to a degree that makes it needlessly complicated. Would absolutely recommend.
Absolutely! Craig is great!
Yes. Trees is a very interesting class with engaging discussion sections, but don't come in expecting it as a gut class.
Trees! I learned a whole lot about trees and actually look at the world a different way now. This class is great!

Id recommend Trees to a student in EVST trying to complete the biology requirement, that has an interest in trees and plants. I did not attend most of the lectures but found the course to be interesting when I did go and a good use of time. The opportunities in section to measure trees, see old instruments and furniture was really interesting. The textbooks were meh, and Rutkows American Canopy very colonially minded and racist for being written in the late 2010s or so. Overall the course is good and informative, just make sure to go.
If they are interested
If there was no section, then yes. Lectures are very interesting and engaging but section feels like a waste of time

HIGHLY RECOMMEND.Yes, it is a gut science class, but the professor anticipates this. He understands that many are simply there to check out a box. However, his style and level of passion and engagement lead students to heavily invest in the course. At least I did. i really delved into the materials and got a lot out of them as a result. The stuff is really fascinating, interesting, and even very applicable. Who would have thought! The professor is GREAT!
Maybe. This class did make me think about and notice trees more which is sort of cool. It wasn't exactly what I was expecting though in a few ways. Still a good class though.
Take it, you won't regret it!
Yes. A good science credit but also learning about trees helps you appreciate nature

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, particularly if you have an interest in nature and haven't had a chance to learn much ecology. This class is also of general interest to students whose interests may be outside of environmental studies; it covers a broad range of topics that touch on sociology, history, music, and many more.

Nice and easy science credit. My one complaint is the multiple choice on the exams - they are worth a good amount and there are usually only two of them and they tend to be tricky, so getting one wrong could drop the exam grade from an A to an A-.
No. Only take it if you absolutely need the science credit.
yes
Yes, especially if they are looking for a fun, accessible science credit.
yes already have.

I would absolutely recommend this course to other students. Whether you are an environmental studies major of just need a science credit, this course was very informative, and genuinely enjoyable for me. Lectures were interesting and assignments were fun.

Yes, but I would really only recommend it to students in an environmental major. I took it to fulfill my biology requirement, and I definitely wouldn't have taken it if I weren't interested in environmental science. Don't take it if you're looking for a gut; there are much easier science credits at Yale.
Took it as a science credit. Deff not a gut so beware, but an interesting course
I don't know if I would be able to recommend this course to another student.  If changes are made, like eliminating section and providing an ecology focus, I would likely recommend it.
Great class for non-Stem majors.
Yes, I really liked this class, and actually found it super interesting when I didn't know I would. Get a good TA though! makes a huge difference.

Y E S !!!!! Such a great class - Professor Brodersen is a fantastic teacher and does so much to engage students (great lectures, fun field trips, etc.). You learn so much interesting stuff about trees and wood - I looooved this class.

I feel like this is a course that I will appreciate more in retrospect than I did while I was taking it. The material is fascinating, but it was sometimes easy to lose sight of that from week to week. Not every lecture landed, and there were stretches in the middle of the semester where the subject matter felt somewhat tedious (lots of memorization of lots of hormones and secondary metabolites), but the first and last thirds had some really fun stuff, especially the last third: I loved learning about how wood is used in violins and really just everyday life--I don't think I'll ever look at a wooden door or table the same way again. 

The workload is perfectly reasonable, though it might be more than you're expecting. Five short online quizzes, five (pretty interactive) homework assignments, weekly reading and section, and two midterms and a final. If you keep a sharp eye on the dates (stuff sneaks up on you) and pace yourself accordingly you should be fine. 

It's not the greatest class, but it does cover a lot of fascinating, even occasionally mind-blowing stuff that you're unlikely to learn anywhere else, and best of all it really sticks with you. Since trees are such a fundamental and ubiquitous feature of life on Earth, you see them everywhere and are reminded of the course material when you do. I really do have a much deeper appreciation for these natural miracles, and I'm glad this course gave me that.

Trees is a fine science credit, though I am sure that there are easier ones out there somewhere. The class is curved so 20% get A's, 20% get A-'s, 20% B+'s, 20% B's, and 20% C's and D's. I know this because he showed it on the first day. That means that a significian portion--more than half--do NOT get A's or A-'s. For people taking this for a Sc, it is worth keeping in mind. 

This is basically a tree biology course. The textbook, Taiz and Zeiger, is dense, and opens a paragraph "As you likely remember from Organic Chemistry," which gives you an idea of how much it is used in the course. I am not sure anyone in the class ever did the readings. Ever. 

There are tests, quizzes, problem sets (which take FOREVER), and participation. It is also at 9am. 

Bottom Line: See if you can find another easy science. If not, this will likely do.
Take this course for a science. It's not exciting or engaging, but its pretty fair. There are some frustrating projects (ie measuring trees) and some fun ones. Don't expect anything life changing.

If you really don't want to take a difficult physics or chemistry class like me and don't have much of a background in science at all, this is a good science credit that's not too hard to understand. If you pay attention to the material you'll be able to get it fine. The only thing is there are a decent number of assignments and exams and there is section so if you want to do well you do have to invest some time to this class (I said some, not a ton). But you do learn a lot about trees and plants in general and much of it will probably stay with you after the class ends just because knowing the details are kind of important. The textbook also has a lot more information than we learned and the TAs are available to meet additionally if you want to learn even more about trees.
The biology portion of the class was interesting and changed my perception of trees. For this alone, I would recommend the class.
Definitely take this course if you are interested in trees and forestry
Yes! A great, substantial science course -- very accessible to non-science majors, and very well-presented.
Yes! Very interesting and a good SC credit.
This is a great science credit for non-science majors.
Yes, especially for non-STEM majors. Good science credit, not too gutty, learn something.
Yes! if you like the environment trees are a great lens to view it through
Yes absolutely! Trees is a fun science course that will give you lots of fun facts about trees and will, in general, help you to have a better understanding of the plant world around you.

I would definitely recommend this course as it is about much more than just trees. It does encapsulate a good deal about environmental science and challenges many preconceived notions about trees and plant life in general.
Yes! This is a great course for those looking for for an introduction to a fundamental topic in biology.
Yes I would because I think its important for anyone to be educated on important factors that affect our environment

I would recommend this course to a friend who understands biology pretty well and is interested in gaining a deeper understanding of trees. The class material refreshes on high school biology at times so be aware of that.
Yes! Great, interesting intro to the biology of trees and forestry!
If you can make it all the way up science hill at 9 am, take this class--its great and you'll do well! If you're not an early riser you won't...

Yes, this is a great class for anyone interested in environmental studies, especially those coming from a non-STEM background. I took it for a science credit because I didn't see myself spending much time with STEM classes, but it has made me much more strongly consider an environmental studies degree. The material is often interesting and not difficult to understand; consistent attendance at lectures and a decent amount of studying for the exams are guarantees of a good grade. It also opens your eyes to some great stuff, like tree height and Maple Fest.
Yes, definitely.  The lectures were interesting, the slideshow presentations were comprehensive, section meetings were helpful, and examinations were fair.

I would recommend it tentatively. If you are particularly interested in trees, the content provides a wonderful overview. The trouble is that the lecture format doesn't really whisk you along, it tends to leave you wishing the subject matter was brought to life more.

Yes. I was worried about getting my science credit because I'm a humanities-type, but the class is set up in a way that makes it accessible to everyone and probably more enjoyable than a different science class.
I would recommend this to anyone who wants a good science credit that isn't too difficult but also teaches you something useful about the world around you.
Yes, if they need a science credit or an introductory course into environmental sciences.
